initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.

Whelan's family members are urging the Biden administration to do everything possible to secure their loved one's freedom.

"We ask that the administration continue to prioritize our brother's case and work tirelessly to bring him home," they said.

The release of Sgt Black comes amid heightened tensions between Washington and Moscow over Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

While the two countries have made some progress on certain issues, such as prisoner exchanges, they remain deeply divided on many others, including sanctions and military assistance to Kyiv.

"The fact that we were able to get Sgt Black back shows that we can make deals with Russia even in times of conflict," a senior Biden administration official said. "That gives us reason to be optimistic about the future."

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he traveled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defense department did not authorize his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.

After months of negotiations between Washington and Moscow, US officials announced on Wednesday that they had secured the release of Sgt Black from Russian custody.

The deal was brokered by President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin during their meeting in Geneva last week, according to a senior administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the matter publicly.

Biden administration officials said the agreement included a promise by Russia not to prosecute Sgt Black further or seek his extradition.

In exchange, the United States agreed to provide medical treatment to a Russian citizen who is being held in a U.S. prison on unrelated charges.

Sergeant Black returned home to Texas earlier this week after spending nearly five months in Russian detention. His family members welcomed him back with open arms.

"I'm just so happy he's safe and sound," his mother, Melody Jones, told CBS News. "It's like a miracle."

Sergeant Black has declined to speak publicly about his time in Russia, but his lawyer, Mark Zaid, described the ordeal as "a nightmare."

"He was kept in solitary confinement for weeks on end, and he was never given any legal representation," Zaid said. "The only time he saw a lawyer was when he met with us."

Zaid added that Sergeant Black suffered from serious health problems while in custody, including pneumonia and dehydration.

Despite the hardships he endured, Sergeant Black remains committed to serving his country, his lawyer said.

"He wants people to know that he loves the United States Army and that he is proud to have served his nation," Zaid said.

As for Gershkovich and Whelan, the Biden administration continues to push for their release as well.

"We will never stop fighting for them," a State Department spokesperson said in a statement. "We call on Russia to immediately and unconditionally release these innocent Americans."

Meanwhile, Whelan's family members are also celebrating the news of Sgt Black's release.

"We're overjoyed that Sgt Black is finally free," Whelan's brother, David, said in a statement. "But our joy is tempered by the fact that Evan Gershkovich and Paul remain behind bars."

Whelan's family members are urging the Biden administration to do everything possible to secure their loved one's freedom.

"We ask that the administration continue to prioritize our brother's case and work tirelessly to bring him home," they said.

The release of Sgt Black comes amid heightened tensions between Washington and Moscow over Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

While the two countries have made some progress on certain issues, such as prisoner exchanges, they remain deeply divided on many others, including sanctions and military assistance to Kyiv.

Still, the resolution of Sgt Black's case provides a glimmer of hope for those who believe that diplomacy can still prevail even in the darkest of times.

"The fact that we were able to get Sgt Black back shows that we can make deals with Russia even in times of conflict," a senior Biden administration official said. "That gives us reason to be optimistic about the future."

But instead of returning to the US, he traveled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

He did not request official clearance and the defense department did not authorize his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.
